section_path: Section IV > A. Selection of first-listed condition > 2. Observation Stay

content.full_text: When a patient is admitted for observation for a medical condition, assign a code for the medical condition as the first-listed diagnosis. When a patient presents for outpatient surgery and develops complications requiring admission to observation, code the reason for the surgery as the first reported diagnosis (reason for the encounter), followed by codes for the complications as secondary diagnoses. (Evidence: pg no: 112, L35-L36)
content.summary: Provides specific coding instructions for observation stays, differentiating between medical observation and post-surgical observation scenarios (Evidence: pg no: 112, L35-L36)
key_concepts: Medical observation: condition being observed is first-listed (Evidence: pg no: 112, L35-L36)
Post-surgical observation: surgical reason remains first-listed (Evidence: pg no: 112, L36)
Complications are coded as secondary diagnoses (Evidence: pg no: 112, L36)

detailed_rules.rule_text: For medical observation, code the medical condition as first-listed diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 112, L35-L36)
detailed_rules.explanation: When observation is for a medical condition, that condition is the reason for the encounter (Evidence: pg no: 112, L35-L36)

detailed_rules.rule_text: For post-surgical observation, code surgical reason first, complications secondary (Evidence: pg no: 112, L36)
detailed_rules.explanation: The original reason for encounter (surgery) remains primary even when complications develop requiring observation (Evidence: pg no: 112, L36)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Determine if observation is for medical condition or post-surgical complication
Step 2: For medical: Code the condition being observed as first-listed
Step 3: For post-surgical: Code the surgical reason as first-listed
Step 4: Code complications as secondary diagnoses
